div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Springfield Republican, July 22, 1906
div1.p:
A deserved tribute to a brave and modest
medical officer who was fortunate enough
to play a foremost part in the discovery of
the cause and mode of prevention of one
of the most terrible of plagues, is given in
the volume entitled “Walter Reed and
Yellow Fever” by Howard A. Kelly,
professor in Johns Hopkins university,
which is published by McClure, Phillips &
Co. The author well says in his preface:
“The inspiration of Reed's life lies to me
in the fact that, though a man of war, he
ravaged no distant land, he destroyed no
tens of thousands to make his reputation,
but by quiet method, when there was no
strife, he saved countless lives and swept
away a hideous plague, which from time
immemorial has periodically visited our
shores.” Very properly the basis of the
book is scientific rather than personal,
though the facts of Reed's fine career are
briefly and simply stated. He was born
in Gloucester county, Va., in 1851, of a
family of English extraction. He was 10
years old when the civil war began and
had some slight glimpses of it as a non-
combatant. His schooling was interrupted
only one year, and he was able to enter the
university of Virginia at 16, a special dis-
pensation being required on account of
his youth. He turned early to medicine,
and realizing that his father's means did
not permit of the whole university course,
he took up medical studies as early as he
could. The author says: “This request was
refused on the ground that he was under
age. He then inquired whether he would
be allowed to take the degree of doctor
if he could pass the examination. To this
this faculty silently assented, thinking that
it was a safe promise, for the undertaking
was an impossibility.” He passed tri-
umphantly. The incident shows the lad's
strong bent toward science. He studied
later at the Bellevue medical hospital in
New York, where for the first time he saw
a large city. As district physician in one
of the poorest districts, he was for the
first time brought into contact with the
poverty and vice of the slums. He married
Miss Emilie Lawrence of a North Carolina
family that had come from Watertown and
Salem, Mass. In 1874 he decided to give
up general practice and entered the army
as a surgeon, feeling that he lacked the
closer connection needed for an early start
in private practice. Several chapters are
devoted to his frontier life, which was pic-
turesque and interesting, but unimportant
in comparison with his scientific work.

In 1889, Dr Reed began to feel the need
for further study, and after some trouble
secured an appointment as attending sur-
geon and examiner of recruits in Baltimore,
Md., with permission to study in the Johns
Hopkins hospital. It is curious to read,
however, that he was curtly and pointedly
forbidden by the then surgeon-general to
take courses in pathology and bacteriology.
He was told that his business was to learn
to take care of sick soldiers. Fortunately
the new surgeon-general was more in sym-
pathy with scientific pursuits, and Dr Reed
was enabled to carry on study in pathology
and bacteriology, without which splendid
later results could not have been obtained.
He took an early stand in favor of the use
of the antitoxin serum, and throughout
showed a disposition to test every new idea.
He was very anxious when the Spanish
war broke out in 1898 to hold some re-
sponsible position in the care of sick sol-
diers, but had the mortification of seeing
untrained men with political influence pre-
ferred. He himself said very frankly in
private conversation, “The army medical
corps has received a black eye because of
the neglect and incompetence of men who
did not really belong to it.” The lesson
of the war as to the need of reorganization
of the medical corps is forcibly pressed
home by the author. Dr Reed's first sci-
entific work during the war was in the
investigation of the typhoid epidemic
among the volunteers, to which he devoted
more than a year as chairman of a com-
mittee, whose report has but lately been
issued by the government. While his part
in this work is not separated from that of
the other members of the committee, its
importance justifies the space given to it
by the author. The chief points in the
report are that the infected water was not
an important factor, that flies undoubtedly
acted as carriers of the infection, and it
is more than likely that men transported
infected material on their persons.

The author takes up the subject of yellow
fever with much thoroughness, devoting
several chapters to the character and his-
tory of the disease. He virtually contra-
dicts the assertion made by several histo-
rians that the fever was brought over from
the west coast of Africa in slave ships, by
saying: “Some of the older writers claim
that yellow fever was originally present in
Africa, though Cortez found it in Mexico.
It was certainly unknown in Europe until
after the discovery of America.” The
history of opinion as to the cause of the
disease and its mode of transmission is
briefly but carefully traced. It is curious to
note that one Prof P. Stille of Mobile, Ala.,
advanced a theory which attributed the
disease to the influence of the Gulf stream.
Dr Labadie favored the “explosive” theory,
that the disease was caused by "a peculiar
subtle poison which exploded in the air
like an inflammable substance, and that
persons who inhaled it or swallowed it in
greater or less quantity fell under its in-
fluence after a certain time. In 1878 medi-
cal experts appointed by Congress pre-
sented a report which was nearer the truth
than the doctrines which prevailed after
that until the discovery of the part played
by the mosquito. For it was about 1878
that “fomites,” the term given to clothing
and other articles which were supposed to
transmit the infection, came into vogue.
The theory on the subject was therefore
turned in to a wrong channel which made
discovery of the truth impossible. The last
official statement under the old order, the
last defense of the old fashioned theories
of yellow fever, was in 1898, when the
United States marine hospital service
issued a report saying: “While yellow fever
is a communicable disease, it is not con-
tagious in the ordinary acceptation of the
term, but is spread by the infection of
places and articles of bedding, clothing and
furniture.”

It was but a year or two before the truth
was made known by the researches in
which Dr Reed had the most important
part and which are still too familiar in the
general mind to require recapitulation, al-
though Dr Kelly's is the first account of it
from the biographical point of view. It
would be hard to find finer examples of
heroism than those offered by the volunteer
soldiers who freely gave their services as
subjects for experiment. One can under-
stand the enthusiasm with which Dr Reed
wrote to his wife: “It is with a great deal
of pleasure that I hasten to tell you that
we have succeeded in producing a case of
unmistakable yellow fever by the bite of a
mosquito. . . . Rejoice with me.” The
patient could not be expected to share his
enthusiasm, but it should be added that he
made a good recovery. Dr Reed's own
feeling is shown in the remark: “Maj Kean
says that the recovery is worth more than
the cost of the Spanish war, including lives
lost and money expended.” This brilliant
achievement was followed soon by his
death, which occurred in 1902, as the result
of an operation for appendicitis.
